body: I am getting the same error.
Might be related to https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/963
@lincleejun, can you try running `npm install keytar` and then re-trying the bootstrap script? That seems to have worked for me.
D'oh, spoke too soon. Looked like it got farther but then failed again.

So far I have tried:
Switching from 64bit to 32bit node (oops, but didn't help).
Uninstalling all .NET frameworks, reinstalling 4.5.1 SDK and runtime.
Installing VS 2013 redists.
Installing VS 2012 Express (but compiling with VS 2013 installed as well. Uninstalling 2013 now).
Installing Windows 8.1 SDK.

So far, nothing. Dependency analysis shows a handful of missing .dlls, but those are missing on every .exe I check, so it's not that.
You do need 32-bit Node, you also need Node 0.10.x; if your node version reports 0.12.x, you are Too Hip And With It™ and need to go back to 0.10.x
Having >1 VS installation will also cause you tears, you really just need _only_ VS2013

Ok, I'll revert to Node 0.10.x, remove 2012, and re-install 2013, and report back.

If the issue is Node 0.10.x vs. 0.12, then it would help having that specified in the build instructions, as opposed to simply 32-bit.

Alright, after installing node 0.10.35, VC Community 2013, I get hung up on a different error on the same step.

```
c:\open\atom-shell\node_modules\atom-package-manager\bin\apm.cmd install
Installing modules failed
npm WARN package.json atom-shell-specs@0.1.0 No description
npm WARN package.json atom-shell-specs@0.1.0 No repository field.
npm WARN package.json atom-shell-specs@0.1.0 No README data
npm ERR! Windows_NT 6.2.9200
npm ERR! argv "c:\\open\\atom-shell\\node_modules\\atom-package-manager\\bin\\\\node.exe" "c:\\open\\atom-shell\\node_modules\\atom-package-manager\\node_modules\\npm\\bin\\npm-cli.js" "--globalconfig
" "c:\\open\\atom-shell\\node_modules\\atom-package-manager\\.apmrc" "--userconfig" "C:\\Users\\akrieger\\.atom\\.apmrc" "install" "--target=0.21.0" "--arch=ia32" "--msvs_version=2013"
npm ERR! node v0.10.35
npm ERR! npm  v2.1.18

npm ERR! uid must be an unsigned int
npm ERR!
npm ERR! If you need help, you may report this error at:
npm ERR!     <http://github.com/npm/npm/issues>
None
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "script/bootstrap.py", line 127, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "script/bootstrap.py", line 35, in main
    update_atom_modules('spec')
  File "script/bootstrap.py", line 77, in update_atom_modules
    execute_stdout([apm, 'install'])
  File "c:\open\atom-shell\script\lib\util.py", line 152, in execute_stdout
    raise e
subprocess.CalledProcessError: Command '['c:\\open\\atom-shell\\node_modules\\atom-package-manager\\bin\\apm.cmd', 'install']' returned non-zero exit status 1
```

I'll mess with it more in the morning. This is after doing a `git clean -fdx; rm -rf vendor/*; git reset --hard HEAD;`
http://pastebin.com/vWh5S5RN is the contents of spec/npm-debug.log
@akrieger After you did the clean, you reran bootstrap.py && build.py? You're not running as an elevated user? You have permission to C:\Open (sorry perhaps dumb questions, grasping at straws here)

Yep, reran bootstrap.py. The error was during bootstrap.py.

I have full perms to C:\open. I am not running as an elevated user (running inside the git shell from http://git-scm.com/download/win).

ls -la output: http://pastebin.com/eewvCj3U
I guess I could re-clone atom-shell and see if it still repro's.

When I do a very-clean build, I get this error the first time running bootstrap.py:

```
  Finished generating code
```

I got the above error about 'uid must be an unsigned int' running bootstrap a second time.
Aaaand on a clean clone and bootstrap I get the same error. 'node-gyp' is not recognized as an internal or external command, etc.

Curiously, npm list shows this:

```
...
│ ├─┬ tough-cookie@0.12.1
│ │ └── punycode@1.3.2
│ └── tunnel-agent@0.4.0
└─┬ runas@2.0.0 extraneous
  └── nan@1.6.1

npm ERR! extraneous: runas@2.0.0 c:\open\atom-shell\node_modules\runas
npm ERR! not ok code 0

akrieger@AKRIEGER-X1 /c/open/atom-shell (master)
```
Just for fun, I'm going to install node into C:\open instead of into program files and see if things magically stop failing.
Wait, are you running under Bash? What happens if you run under 'cmd'? Atom Shell build is known to fail under Bash and friends
Huh. It magically just works if I run it under powershell.
In theory the bash shell should have all the same path semantics as powershell. But maybe not? Interactions with env may be weird in the git bash.
Ok, well. @lincleejun, try node 0.10.x. @paulcbetts, can you update the docs to specify node 0.10.x as well as 32-bit?
Now I just get generic build errors. Sigh. I can open a new issue for those assuming I can't resolve them.

The Windows build doc already says 32bit Node is required to build. It's not totally clear why we need to still use Node 0.10.x to bootstrap since at least the latest version of Atom-Shell uses io.js internally. I just tried bootstrapping on io.js 1.2.0 and it failed. I'm sure there is a good explanation for this that I am not aware of. I always use the Visual Studio 2013 command prompt to build and have never had a problem as long as I color within the lines. Just saying.

https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/blob/master/docs/development/build-instructions-windows.md

Yep, fair. I also just scrolled to the end of the build instructions and saw the message about exactly the second error I had, using git bash.

Sorry, new to Windows dev :) I thought the 'git bash' that ships with the git install is just a wrapper around cmd.exe that adds some stuff to the path, I didn't realize it was actually some weird bash port.

Like I mentioned earlier, I got more hung up more on the node 0.10.x requirement than the 32 vs 64 bit problem. The 'oops' part of my comment was because I re-read the instructions to use 32 bit, so that was the first thing I tried and it didn't help.

While most of your comment was helpful, 'just saying' is frivolous and feels like you're 'just' talking down to me. Thank you for your help and additional insight into the Node 0.10 / 0.12 issue.
@akrieger It shouldn't be this hard, but a lot of the fragility is because of Chrome, but the rest should be on us to make it fall over less. Thanks for putting up with the frustration

I'm also getting build errors. I'm using Windows 8.1 with VS 2013 community edition. From the Developers' Tools Command Prompt with a clean checkout:

```
C:\atom-shell>python --version
Python 2.7.6

C:\atom-shell>node -v
v0.10.36

C:\atom-shell>python script\bootstrap.py
C:\atom-shell>python script\build.py
ninja: Entering directory `out\Release'
[51/955] CC obj\vendor\node\deps\uv\src\win\libuv.fs.obj
c:\atom-shell\vendor\node\deps\uv\src\win\fs.c(809) : warning C4210: nonstandard extension used : function given file scope
[353/955] CC obj\vendor\node\deps\open...enssl\crypto\dso\openssl.dso_win32.obj
c:\atom-shell\vendor\node\deps\openssl\openssl\crypto\dso\dso_win32.c(300) : warning C4055: 'type cast' : from data pointer 'void *' to function pointer 'DSO_FUNC_TYPE'
[674/955] CXX obj\atom\common\atom_lib.node_bindings.obj
FAILED: ninja -t msvc -e environment.x86 -- "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 12.0\VC\bin\amd64_x86\cl.exe" /nologo /showIncludes /FC @obj\atom\common\atom_lib.node_bindings.obj.rsp /c ..\..\atom\common\node_bindings.cc /Foobj\atom\common\atom_lib.node_bindings.obj /Fdobj\atom_lib.cc.pdb
c:\atom-shell\atom\common\node_bindings.cc(181) : error C2065: 'Lprocess_type' : undeclared identifier
c:\atom-shell\atom\common\node_bindings.cc(182) : error C2228: left of '.Append' must have class/struct/union
c:\atom-shell\atom\common\node_bindings.cc(183) : error C2228: left of '.Append' must have class/struct/union
[674/955] CXX obj\atom\common\atom_lib.common_message_generator.obj
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
```

A little more investigation. These are the offending lines:

```
  const char* process_type = is_browser_ ? "browser" : "renderer";
  base::FilePath resources_path = GetResourcesPath(command_line, is_browser_);
  base::FilePath script_path =
      resources_path.Append(FILE_PATH_LITERAL("atom.asar"))
                    .Append(FILE_PATH_LITERAL(process_type))
                    .Append(FILE_PATH_LITERAL("lib"))
                    .Append(FILE_PATH_LITERAL("init.js"));

```

If I change `.Append(FILE_PATH_LITERAL(process_type))` to `.Append(FILE_PATH_LITERAL("browser"))` then the build succeeds (not tried with "renderer"). Could this be `const char*` vs literal UTF8?
That is a different problem than the one I and @lincleejun were having. See https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/pull/1147

@akreiger - apologies for hijacking the thread. Your pull request appears to solve my problem, so thanks for that. In case anyone else stumbles upon the issue I had, I can now do a successful build using:
- node 0.10.36 (32-bit)
- python 2.7.6
- Visual Studio 2013 Community Edition

The build worked in the "Developer Command Prompt for VS2013", which may not be present in your start screen if you're using 8.1 (I had to hunt it out).
OMG, so many comments :)... But thanks guys, it help me fix the building problem....thx...

using node v0.12 (64-bit) and built atom-shell successfully after making changes to apm download v0.12 node https://github.com/deepak1556/apm and applying @akrieger changes to `FILE_PATH_LITERAL` macro on windows https://github.com/deepak1556/atom-shell/tree/nodev0.12 . Is this good ? ;)
![atom-shell](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/964386/6412288/d1000bb8-bea7-11e4-8310-acd2a1253805.jpg)
#1147 has been fixed and it seems that op's problem has also been solved, so I'm closing this.
